author: @impossibleexperiments
text: I implemented my controls slightly different from what you see in the video. Because of this my car would move on its own after the "you crashed" message was displayed for 2 seconds. If this happens but also in general it's a good idea to call pygame.event.clear() when setting up a new game. This will clear any pending events (keys held down or released) from the previous run.

author: @harri4007
text: It took me all day but I finally figured out what was throwing that "can't find font" error.  I changed this:  largeText = pygame.font.Font('freesansbold.ttf',115) TextSurf, TextRect = text_objects(text, largeText)   Instead it now reads like this:  font = pygame.font.SysFont('arial', 115) TextSurf, TextRect = text_objects(text, font)  for some reason python wasn't recognizing "largeText".  I don't know it it'll help anyone but it's worth a shot.

author: @xXParzivalXx
text: At 8:30, when you/we call the game_loop function, isn't that recursion? Assuming we have the event of our car reaching the borders of the screen, the game_loop function is called again and "takes over" the whole program, while the initial game_loop function will never finish running (unless aborted by the pygame.quit and quit methods/functions). And this happens every time the car crashes. While in this case there is probably not a big memory hole involved, it does make it way harder to "run the program in your head", and it looks kinda "unclean" to me. Also, it might be better to get the whole reset-the-game stuff out of the message_display function so we can use it for displaying messages that should not reset the game.

author: @ulyssesmayo7834
text: Nice tutorial.  Just adding information for Wing IDE users -- it is probably best to import 'sys', then add sys.exit() below pygame.quit() if the event.type == pygame.QUIT
